an4.16:1.1: “Mendicants, there are these four kinds of subtlety.
an4.16:1.3: A mendicant has ultimate subtlety of form.
an4.16:1.4: They don’t see any other subtlety of form that’s better or finer than that,
an4.16:1.5: nor do they aim for it.
an4.16:1.6: A mendicant has ultimate subtlety of feeling.
an4.16:1.7: They don’t see any other subtlety of feeling that’s better or finer than that,
an4.16:1.8: nor do they aim for it.
an4.16:1.9: A mendicant has ultimate subtlety of perception.
an4.16:1.10: They don’t see any other subtlety of perception that’s better or finer than that,
an4.16:1.11: nor do they aim for it.
an4.16:1.12: A mendicant has ultimate subtlety of choices.
an4.16:1.13: They don’t see any other subtlety of choices that’s better or finer than that,
an4.16:1.14: nor do they aim for it.
an4.16:1.15: These are the four kinds of subtlety.
an4.16:3.2: peaceful, in love with the state of peace.
an4.16:3.4: having vanquished Māra and his mount.”
